title: 107_s879
content: The Act titled "Cosmetology Tax Fairness and Compliance Act of 2001" expands the credit for a portion of Social Security taxes paid with respect to employee tips. The Act "Cosmetology Tax Fairness and Compliance Act of 2001" expands the credit for employee tips in certain lines of business, such as food and beverage services and cosmetology services at licensed facilities. The "Cosmetology Tax Fairness and Compliance Act of 2001" expands the definition of cosmetology service to include hairdressing, haircutting, manicures, pedicures, body waxing, facials, and other beauty-related services provided at licensed facilities. The amendments apply to tips received for services performed after December 31, 2001. SEC. 6050T. RETURNS RELATING TO COSMETOLOGY SERVICES AND INFORMATION TO BE PROVIDED TO COSMETOLOGISTS. Every person who employs cosmetologists, rents chairs to cosmetologists, or receives compensation from cosmetologists must comply with return and taxpayer education requirements. Compliance is determined by meeting specific criteria outlined in the subsection. Employees and independent contractors in the cosmetology industry must meet specific requirements related to reporting employee receipts, tip reporting, and compensation payments to comply with tax regulations. Employees and independent contractors in the cosmetology industry must meet specific requirements related to reporting employee receipts, tip reporting, and compensation payments to comply with tax regulations. Chair renters who receive rent or fees from cosmetologists for more than 5 days in a year must make a return according to prescribed forms or regulations. Chair renters in the cosmetology industry must report the amount received from each cosmetologist to the Secretary, along with providing a written statement to each cosmetologist showing the information contact details and the received amount. The reporting person must inform the IRS that the cosmetologist provided services during the year. A written statement must be provided to the cosmetologist by January 31 of the following year. Taxpayer education requirements apply in this case. Taxpayer education requirements for reporting persons include providing an annual publication to cosmetologists, explaining tax and tip reporting obligations for employees and tax obligations for independent contractors or proprietorships. Publications can be given in person or by first-class mail with proper notice enclosed. The term 'cosmetologist' refers to an individual providing cosmetology services, with the possibility of expansion to include entities to prevent reporting requirement circumvention. 'Cosmetology service' is defined as per section 45B(c), and 'chair' encompasses furniture or equipment used for providing cosmetology services. The subsection exempts reporting persons from reporting tips for employees in non-tipping roles. Amendments to the Code include adding a new clause for cosmetology service providers. The subsection exempts reporting persons from reporting tips for employees in non-tipping roles. It includes adding a new clause for cosmetology service providers in section 6050T. Effective Date: The amendments made by this section apply to calendar years after 2001 for cosmetology services.
